newsitem.title: CANADA: Alumax mulls expansion of Lauralco - paper.
newsitem.headline: Alumax mulls expansion of Lauralco - paper.

text.p: Alumax Inc is studying the possibility of investing hundreds of million of dollars to expand its Lauralco smelter in Deschambault, Quebec, Le Soleil newspaper said on Friday.
The investment is conditional to reaching an agreement with government-owned untility Hydro-Quebec on preferential electricity rates, the Quebec City newspaper said.
"It could be as big as a second Lauralco," Jean-Pierre Gilardeau, director general of the smelter, told the newspaper.
Earlier this week, Alumax chief executive Allen Born told reporters in Atlanta that the company was looking at the possibility of expanding low-cost Lauralco.
The smelter was built in the early 1990s at a cost of C$1 billion, and produced 217,000 metric tons of aluminum in 1996.
A Hydro-Quebec spokeswoman told Reuters that the utility has no plans to negotiate a special rate with Alumax.
"We do not want to negotiate the rate with Alumax. There is a fixed rate for large companies," said Francine Charest.
Special rates offered by Hydro-Quebec to large smelters and metal-making facilities have been a controversial issue in Quebec after reports indicated they were dampening profits at the utility.
